bibl.title: Letter from Dorothy Blondel to John J. Moran, January 13, 1930

div1.p: Blondel, on behalf of the New York Association of Biology Teachers, congratulates Moran for his yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Dorothy Blondel to John J. Moran, January 13, 1930
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION
THE CITY OF NEW YORK
----
GEORGE WASHINGTON HIGH SCHOOL
192ND STREET AND AUDUBON AVE.
MANHATTAN
----
ARTHUR A. BOYLAN, PRINCIPAL
NEW YORK, January 13, 1930.
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
The New York Association of Biology Teachers has been
considering anew the work of the Army Commission in eradi-
cating the terrible scourge of Yellow Fever. They were
greatly impressed by your record in this work and by the
attitude you have taken since, and by your activity in
trying to help some of the other members of that commission.

At the last business meeting of the Association, it was
unanimously voted that resolutions be sent to you expressing
feeling of admiration that your record has aroused in the
minds of all who have had occasions to study into this sub-
ject. I take great pleasure in forwarding in this informal
manner, the feeling of this meeting, that you have performed
a service of inestimable benefit to humanity which is an in-
spiration to all who have any hard task to face.

The Biology teachers of New York feel it a great ad-
vantage to be able to present, in teaching the topic of
Yellow Fever, the story of your heroic action. May I send
you the best wishes of the Association?
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Dorothy Blondel, Cor. Sec. DB:BK
